Putting a face to 'Big Brother'
 
 Literally putting a face on technology could be one of the keys to improving our interaction with hi-tech gadgets.
 
 Imagine a surveillance system that also presents a virtual embodiment of a person on a screen who can react to your behaviour, and perhaps even alert you to new e-mails. Basic versions of these so-called avatars already exist. Together with speech and voice recognition systems, they could replace the keyboard and mouse in the near future. Some of these ideas have been showcased at the London's Science Museum, as part of its Future Face exhibition.
 
 One such avatar is Jeremiah. It is a virtual man, which you can download for free and install in your computer.
 
 His creator, Richard Bowden, lecturer at the Centre for Vision, Speech and Signal Processing at the University of Surrey, refers to Jeremiah as "him", rather than it. "Jeremiah is a virtual face that attempts to emulate humans in the way it responds to activity. He is very childlike, he likes visual stimulus," he told the BBC News website. "When he sees children running and laughing and waving at him, he smiles at them. If you ignore him, he gets angry. If you leave, he gets sad. And you can also even surprise him." Jeremiah is not actually intelligent. It works on vision, reacting in a preset way to the information provided by a surveillance tracker system. It is not able to talk or to hear you, at least not yet. The Surrey team is already working on Jeremiah's next version, that will replace the human face with an underwater and more interactive creature: Finn the fish. "I am interested in the interaction, providing the ability of a system to watch what's going on and make decisions based on that," explained Dr Bowden.
 
 The research comes at a time when people are having to cope with an increasing number of hi-tech gadgets.
 
 Experts say a much more natural way to interact with these devices, such as a virtual human, could make it much easier to make the most of all those new gizmos. "If you get up at three o'clock in the morning, and you go downstairs, there are probably two things you are going to do: either going to the bathroom, or maybe you are going to make a cup of tea," said Dr Bowden. "Now if the system can watch your behaviour over time, it can learn this, so it would predict what you are going to do, turn on the lights for you, or, before you even get to the kettle, it could have switched it on." You might even be able to tell your home surveillance system that you will be going away on holiday, and ask if it could make sure that the house is secure once you have left. This might sound like a scary vision of an Orwellian future. But it might all depend on the face that is watching you. "When we put the surveillance cameras in our centre, a lot of people were very unhappy about the fact that there was a system watching them," said Dr Bowden. "But when Jeremiah's camera went in, nobody minded, because although it's still watching them, they could see what it was watching."

Consider a scenario where you are designing an artificial intelligence system for a smart home.
This AI system has the ability to learn from user's behavior, just like Dr. Richard Bowden’s Jeremiah avatar.
The system must be able to monitor different tasks a person may do at 3:00 am and 7:00 pm when he/she is alone in the house.

The tasks are as follows: 
1.

Going to the bathroom (B)
2.

Making coffee (C)
3.

Checking email (E)
4.

Watching TV (T)
5.

Making tea (M)
6.

Exercising (X)
7.

Reading a book (R)
8.

Taking a shower (S)
9.

Sleeping (P)
10.

Any other task

The AI system has to predict the sequence of tasks for each time slot, but it should not consider 'making coffee' and 'watching TV' as two consecutive actions in a single day because both require a hot beverage.

Rules:
1.
The system must learn from user's behavior over time; hence, it can remember previous actions and predict the future ones.
It cannot make any assumptions about the user's routine unless explicitly told by the user.
If two tasks are similar (like making coffee, making tea), they should always be in different places on the house's floor plan (like separate rooms) to avoid confusion.

The system must not predict actions that directly contradict with a person’s preferences or lifestyle (for example, if the user dislikes exercise, it shouldn't suggest an active activity like exercising).
Question: Given this information and considering that the house layout is fixed and can only accommodate a limited number of rooms for different tasks.
How would you design the AI system to predict what task each user will do at 3:00 am and 7:00 pm?
Firstly, we need to identify which actions are 'hot' and can be combined in one location based on user's preference.

Actions like making coffee or tea, reading a book, and taking a shower are considered as hot because they require a specific type of environment (e.g., the kitchen for making coffee, bedroom for reading).
Next, consider the house layout.
If there is only one room in the house that meets user's needs (for example, bathroom), then predict any activity that requires this room can be done at 3:00 am and 7:00 pm.
For tasks like exercising or making tea which do not require a hot environment, but need space for movement, these can be predicted to happen anywhere in the house.
Now, we have to consider user's habits over time and learn from previous days' actions to make predictions.
If a person usually makes coffee at 7:00 pm then predict that he/she will do it on 3:00 am as well.
If the AI system is taught about the lifestyle of users, it can avoid predicting tasks like exercising if it knows a user has other commitments or preferences (like reading in bed).
Remember to respect the rule that these predictions should not contradict with user's preferences.
For example, if a person likes to exercise but hates waking up early, don't predict any task related to it at 3:00 am.
Finally, use proof by exhaustion approach by considering all possible sequences of tasks for each time slot and choose the one which satisfies all the rules.
Answer: The AI system can be designed as a behavior prediction model that learns from user's habits over time using a fixed house layout with different rooms representing different tasks.
These predictions will not directly contradict with user’s preferences or lifestyle, unless explicitly mentioned otherwise by the user.
